name: Resveratrol
summary: Resveratrol is a natural polyphenol with antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties, studied for cardiovascular, metabolic, and neuroprotective benefits, as well as potential roles in aging and mental health.
description: Resveratrol is a polyphenolic compound found in red grapes, wine, peanuts, and certain berries. It has been widely studied for its ability to activate sirtuin pathways, particularly SIRT1, which are involved in longevity, cellular repair, and stress resistance. Preclinical studies suggest neuroprotective, cardioprotective, and anti-inflammatory effects, with potential applications in cognitive health, mood regulation, and metabolic disorders. However, clinical evidence remains mixed, with issues of bioavailability limiting therapeutic effectiveness.

metadata.natural_source: Red grapes, red wine, berries, peanuts
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for medical indications)

off_label_uses: Adjunctive support in depression and anxiety
contraindications: Bleeding disorders (may have mild antiplatelet effects)
monitoring_required: Bleeding risk if combined with anticoagulants
Liver function with long-term or high-dose use

items: May improve insulin sensitivity and metabolic health
Potential neuroprotective role in aging and cognitive function

sections.text: Resveratrol acts through multiple mechanisms including antioxidant activity, anti-inflammatory effects via NF-κB inhibition, and activation of sirtuin pathways (especially SIRT1). These pathways are implicated in cellular stress resistance, DNA repair, and longevity. In the brain, resveratrol may support mitochondrial function and reduce oxidative stress, potentially protecting against neurodegeneration.

adult.note: Higher doses (up to 1000 mg/day) have been studied in clinical trials, but absorption and bioavailability are limited.

sections.text: Antioxidant and vascular effects may appear within weeks; neuroprotective and longevity-related effects require long-term use and remain experimental.

other: Bioavailability is low; effects may be limited without enhanced formulations.
Use with caution in individuals on blood thinners.
Long-term safety of high-dose supplementation is not established.

items: Liver function with high-dose or prolonged use

sections.pregnancy: Avoid due to lack of safety data
sections.geriatrics: Generally safe at moderate doses; monitor for drug interactions

sections.text: No tapering required; can be discontinued without withdrawal.

items: Often cited as a key compound in the 'French paradox' related to red wine and cardiovascular health.
Most clinical evidence suggests modest benefit, limited by poor bioavailability.
Research ongoing in neurodegenerative and psychiatric disorders, but results remain preliminary.
